newsitem.title: IRAQ: Bahraini MPs in humanitarian mission to Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Bahraini MPs in humanitarian mission to Iraq.

text.p: Two Bahraini MPs visited Iraq on Wednesday for the first time since the 1991 Gulf War over Kuwait.

"Me and brother Mohammed Hassan Kamaladdin are here to assess humanitarian conditions of Iraqis suffering from the (U.N.) embargo," Ali Ben Jabr al-Moslem of the Bahraini Shora council (parliament) told Reuters.
He said they brought medicine but would arrange more food and medical aid to ease problems caused by the stringent U.N. sanctions imposed on Iraq for its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
Iraq gave the Bahrainis a red-carpet welcome, with the official Iraqi News Agency reporting their meetings with senior officials including speaker of the National Assembly Saadoun Hammadi.
Iraq is not allowed to export oil but under an oil-for-food deal with the United Nations Baghdad has been allowed since December to sell oil worth $2 billion every six months to pay for urgent needs.
Iraq on Tuesday complained that food supplies under the deal were taking too long to arrive but U.N. and U.S. officials said Baghdad was hindering operations.
Last Novemeber Bahraini businessmen visited Baghdad to seek deals under the oil-for-food pact. Bahraini officials denied they were sent by the government.

Iraq's relations with Arab Gulf states have been strained since the invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Bahrain and other Gulf allies backed the U.S.-led multinational force that drove Iraqi troops from the emirate in 1991.
Oman, Qatar and to some extent the United Arab Emirates have improved ties with Baghdad but Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reject direct dealings.
